metadata.title: Byblos Script Master Lexicon — Consolidated v4.1 (Phase 6–8 Synthesis)

merge_policy.alternates: Phase 8 'Expanded' values kept under alternate_readings with their stated confidence
merge_policy.conflict_resolution: Prefer Phase 6 unless later phases show higher internal-consistency; none overrode baseline in this consolidation

signs.glyph_description: Vertical line with horizontal bar at top
signs.notes: Vowel system validation + divine determinative function confirmed
variant_forms: Dunand E7 variant, I1 variant (linear style)
signs.svg_glyph: <svg width="30" height="30" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M10,5 L10,25 M5,5 L15,5" stroke="black" stroke-width="2" fill="none"/></svg>

alternate_readings.notes: Pronounced /ʔa/. Represents the glottal stop + a vowel (as in Semitic *ʾalef*). Also used as a logogram for “one/singular” or as a divine name marker (similar to a Sumerian dingir sign). Often appears at beginnings of names or phrases.

variant_forms: Dunand B3 & B1 (foot-like variants interpreted as same 'B' sound)
signs.svg_glyph: <svg width="30" height="30" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M5,25 L5,10 L15,5 L25,10 L25,25 Z M15,15 L15,25" stroke="black" stroke-width="2" fill="none"/></svg>

signs.glyph_description: Three wavy horizontal lines representing water
signs.svg_glyph: <svg width="30" height="30" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M5,8 Q10,5 15,8 T25,8 M5,15 Q10,12 15,15 T25,15 M5,22 Q10,19 15,22 T25,22" stroke="black" stroke-width="2" fill="none"/></svg>

alternate_readings.notes: Pronounced /ga/ (tentative). Might correspond to the Semitic *g* (as in *gimmel*). Identified by similarity to a Phoenician gimel shape and context in possible words (e.g. in a suspected word *gdl* “great”). Moderate frequency. Confidence is lower pending more attestations.

variant_forms: Dunand H6, G17, E12 (stylistic variants of the sun/eye sign)
signs.svg_glyph: <svg width="30" height="30" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><circle cx="15" cy="15" r="10" stroke="black" stroke-width="2" fill="none"/><circle cx="15" cy="15" r="2" fill="black"/></svg>

signs.glyph_description: Curved sinuous line resembling a snake
signs.svg_glyph: <svg width="30" height="30" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M5,20 Q10,10 15,20 T25,20 Q30,10 35,20" stroke="black" stroke-width="2" fill="none"/></svg>

signs.cultural_context: Maritime tools, ship rigging, connection devices
signs.svg_glyph: <svg width="30" height="30" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M15,5 L15,25 M5,15 L25,15" stroke="black" stroke-width="2" fill="none"/></svg>

alternate_readings.notes: Pronounced /ta/ (or generic /t/ with inherent vowel). Visually similar to the Egyptian 'bread loaf' (t) or an X/taw. Appears at the start of certain words (e.g. *ta-ḥu* "living"), indicating a T sound is needed. Medium confidence; assignment supported by cross-script analogies (Proto-Sinaitic taw) and improving internal reads.

signs.svg_glyph: <svg width="30" height="30" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M15,5 L5,25 L25,25 Z" stroke="black" stroke-width="2" fill="none"/></svg>

alternate_readings.notes: Pronounced /gi/ (tentative). Identified in contexts implying a word like *gi* or *qi* meaning 'high/sacred'. For instance, in the phrase interpreted as “sacred mountain”, *B007-B018* was read as "gi-mountain" (holy mountain). Also appears after the fish sign in "living fish" phrase as a possible suffix. Low confidence – could alternatively represent a different sound (e.g. /qi/ or /ki/). Further research needed.

signs.svg_glyph: <svg width="30" height="30" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M5,15 L25,15 M10,10 L10,20 M15,10 L15,20 M20,10 L20,20" stroke="black" stroke-width="2" fill="none"/></svg>

alternate_readings.notes: Pronounced /ša/. Acrophonically from a comb or teeth (*šin*). Confirmed by frequent occurrence in sequences like *B008-B002* (ša-ba-...), which helped identify names and titles (e.g. a name starting with Ša- or the title *šapānu* meaning judge in one reading). Not distinguished from /sa/ in this script (Semitic *s* vs *š* merged here). High confidence due to cross-script support (Egyptian comb = š) and internal usage.

signs.svg_glyph: <svg width="30" height="30" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><rect x="5" y="5" width="20" height="20" stroke="black" stroke-width="2" fill="none"/><path d="M15,5 L15,25 M5,15 L25,15" stroke="black" stroke-width="1"/></svg>

alternate_readings.notes: Pronounced /ḫa/ (voiceless velar fricative with vowel a, like *ḥa* or *kha*). Identified in the formula *B002-B020-B009* ("by the hand of") where it provides the final *ḫa* sound (*-ḫa* resembles the Old Persian genitive “-šá/*-hyā*”). Also appears with B005 (na-ḫa) in an epithet read as “protector”. Confidence moderate; matches a needed Semitic *ḫ* sound, and the sign’s shape has Egyptian analogs (loop or coil for /ḫ/).

signs.cultural_context: Receiving goods, cupping water, hand gestures
signs.svg_glyph: <svg width="30" height="30" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M15,15 m-8,0 a8,8 0 1,1 16,0 a6,6 0 1,1 -12,0 a4,4 0 1,1 8,0 a2,2 0 1,1 -4,0" stroke="black" stroke-width="2" fill="none"/></svg>

alternate_readings.notes: Pronounced /ḥu/ (pharyngeal H + u, similar to Arabic ḥu-). Interpreted as conveying the concept “life” or “living”. Key evidence from *B006-B010* = *ta-ḥu* (transliterated as “living”), and Egyptian parallels (the spiral signifies breath or life-force). Possibly interchangeable with /ḫu/ in some contexts. Confidence is moderate-high after Phase 2’s breakthrough on a small inscription (“sacred living fish”).

signs.cultural_context: Shepherd's staff, teaching implements, guidance tools
signs.svg_glyph: <svg width="30" height="30" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M10,5 L10,25 M20,5 L20,25 M10,10 L20,10 M10,15 L20,15 M10,20 L20,20" stroke="black" stroke-width="2" fill="none"/></svg>

<svg width="30" height="30" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M5,15 L10,10 L20,10 L25,15 L20,20 L15,18 L10,20 Z" stroke="black" stroke-width="2" fill="none"/><circle cx="22" cy="12" r="1" fill="black"/></svg>

alternate_readings.notes: Represents the concept “bird” or fowl. Used as a logographic determinative or noun in contexts like offerings of "fish and fowl":contentReference[oaicite:154]{index=154}:contentReference[oaicite:155]{index=155}. Also appears in a divine epithet interpreted as "Baal of the Sun" where B012 alongside the sun sign suggests a solar bird or sky element (perhaps referencing a bird emblem of a sun deity). Not usually used as a pure syllable, though if phonetic it might correspond to /mu/ or /ṣu/ (uncertain). Medium confidence as logogram (clear pictographic meaning), low as phonetic.

signs.svg_glyph: <svg width="30" height="30" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><circle cx="15" cy="5" r="3" stroke="black" stroke-width="2" fill="none"/><path d="M15,8 L15,18 M10,12 L20,12 M15,18 L10,25 M15,18 L20,25" stroke="black" stroke-width="2" fill="none"/></svg>

alternate_readings.notes: Represents “man, person” and specifically a royal or important person. Used as a determinative before personal names to indicate a human subject, often a **king**. In context, B013 prefixed to a name essentially reads “King [Name]”. It likely carries the meaning *malik* (“king”) or a general ‘person’ classifier. Not used for a syllable value in normal writing (if needed, the phonetic *mu/*mi or *š* could be implied, but we treat it as non-phonetic). Confidence is high in its logographic function, given its placement and comparison to similar usage of a seated king determinative in Egyptian texts:contentReference[oaicite:156]{index=156}:contentReference[oaicite:157]{index=157}.

signs.svg_glyph: <svg width="30" height="30" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M15,25 L15,15 M10,10 L15,15 L20,10 M8,12 L15,15 L22,12 M6,14 L15,15 L24,14" stroke="black" stroke-width="2" fill="none"/></svg>

alternate_readings.notes: Represents “tree, wood, plant”. Found in contexts related to nature or offerings, for example paired with the water sign (B017) to denote “wood and water” as elements of a ritual or inventory:contentReference[oaicite:158]{index=158}:contentReference[oaicite:159]{index=159}. May also serve as a determinative for items of wood or a symbol of growth/fertility. Not used phonetically. Medium confidence (clear pictograph but limited occurrences).

signs.svg_glyph: <svg width="30" height="30" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M5,15 L20,15 L25,10 L25,20 Z M8,12 L12,15 L8,18" stroke="black" stroke-width="2" fill="none"/></svg>

alternate_readings.notes: Represents “fish”. Appears in lists or phrases of offerings (e.g. "fish and birds" where B015 is followed by B012):contentReference[oaicite:160]{index=160}. In one inscription, part of the phrase “sacred living fish” (*ta-ḥu-[fish]-gi*), where B015 clearly denotes the fish itself:contentReference[oaicite:161]{index=161}:contentReference[oaicite:162]{index=162}. Not used as a phonetic sign (if needed, could correspond to /nu/ from Semitic *nūn*, but we see it as a logogram). High confidence in semantic value due to pictographic clarity.

signs.svg_glyph: <svg width="30" height="30" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><circle cx="15" cy="15" r="5" stroke="black" stroke-width="2" fill="none"/><path d="M15,5 L15,8 M25,15 L22,15 M15,25 L15,22 M5,15 L8,15 M21,9 L19,11 M21,21 L19,19 M9,9 L11,11 M9,21 L11,19" stroke="black" stroke-width="1"/></svg>

alternate_readings.notes: Represents “Sun” and by extension “divine, illustrious”. Used as a determinative accompanying divine names or titles (e.g. appears alongside Baʿal or after a king’s name to denote a deified status or epithet “the radiant”):contentReference[oaicite:163]{index=163}:contentReference[oaicite:164]{index=164}. Also forms part of epithets like “Baal Shamash” where it literally denotes the sun. Not typically used as a phonetic *ra* in our texts (that role is filled by B004). High confidence as a semantic marker, given its consistent use and parallels in Egyptian (the sun disk marking divinity):contentReference[oaicite:165]{index=165}:contentReference[oaicite:166]{index=166}.

signs.svg_glyph: <svg width="30" height="30" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M5,15 Q10,10 15,15 T25,15 Q30,10 35,15" stroke="black" stroke-width="2" fill="none"/></svg>

alternate_readings.notes: Pronounced /ma/ when used phonetically, and represents “water” as a logogram. Iconically depicts water. In some texts it stands alone to mean “water” (e.g. after lists of offerings to indicate libations):contentReference[oaicite:167]{index=167}:contentReference[oaicite:168]{index=168}. It also appears in compound words; for example, possibly in a word for “nation/people” (*ʿam*, where B019-**B017** might be read ʿa-m). Etymologically tied to Semitic *mayim* (water) and the letter *mem*. Confidence is fairly high, reinforced by its clear pictographic meaning and analogous use of water determinatives in Egyptian and Mesopotamian texts.

signs.svg_glyph: <svg width="30" height="30" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M5,25 L10,15 L15,20 L20,10 L25,25 Z" stroke="black" stroke-width="2" fill="none"/></svg>

alternate_readings.notes: Represents “mountain” or a sacred hill. Appears in context with B007 as “sacred mountain” in a foundation text:contentReference[oaicite:169]{index=169}:contentReference[oaicite:170]{index=170}. Likely used to denote a holy place or the concept of a *tumuli* or *high place* (which fits Byblos’ religious landscape of high places). Possibly drawn as a triangle or a cluster of peaks. Confidence moderate; the identification fits context and pictography, and parallels exist (Sumerian *KUR* determinative for land/mountain).

signs.cultural_context: Fishing, maritime food sources, aquatic trade
signs.svg_glyph: <svg width="30" height="30" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M5,15 Q15,10 25,15 Q15,20 5,15" stroke="black" stroke-width="2" fill="none"/><circle cx="15" cy="15" r="2" fill="black"/></svg>

alternate_readings.notes: Pronounced /ʿa/ (pharyngeal *ayin* with vowel a). Possibly corresponds to Proto-Sinaitic *ʿayin* (eye). It appears in words like *ʿam* (“people”):contentReference[oaicite:171]{index=171} and *ʿir* (“city”):contentReference[oaicite:172]{index=172} (both tentative readings where B019 initiates the word). In one inscription, B019-B011 was read as *ʾl* (El):contentReference[oaicite:173]{index=173}:contentReference[oaicite:174]{index=174}, hinting B019 might sometimes serve as /ʾa/ as well. Thus, it may cover the range of guttural “a” sounds. Confidence is medium; the sign is clearly needed for certain words, but distinguishing its use from B001’s use is subtle.

signs.svg_glyph: <svg width="30" height="30" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M15,25 L15,15 M12,15 L12,10 M15,15 L15,8 M18,15 L18,10 M21,15 L21,12" stroke="black" stroke-width="2" fill="none"/></svg>

alternate_readings.notes: Pronounced /ya/. Depicts a hand (**Semitic *yad***). Functions phonetically as *ya* (or generic /y/ sound) and logographically as the word “hand”. A signature usage is in the phrase **b-yad** ("by the hand of") where B002 (b-) + B020 (hand) convey authorship or agency:contentReference[oaicite:175]{index=175}:contentReference[oaicite:176]{index=176}. Also could denote “hand” in inventory contexts. Strong cross-validation: the word *yad* meaning hand is pan-Semitic, and Old Arabian Musnad script similarly has a hand symbol for /ka/ or as a word. Confidence high due to formulaic usage in multiple texts.

Represents the number 7. Found as a group of seven tick marks in a row at the end of a short inscription (interpreted as part of a date or list):contentReference[oaicite:177]{index=177}:contentReference[oaicite:178]{index=178}. Dhorme (1946) recognized this as a numeral. We treat B021 as the formal sign for the numeral '7' (possibly read *šabʿat* in Semitic). It may also imply a generic plural or completion. No phonetic value apart from its word for 'seven'. High confidence as a numeral given the clear repetition of seven marks and comparative use of strokes for numbers in other scripts.

signs.glyph_description: Tree or tall plant with branches
signs.notes: Cedar trees, precious wood, primary export
